awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SaTC: Early-Stage Interdisciplinary Collaboration: Privacy-Preserving Mobile Data Collection for Social and Behavioral Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Social and behavioral research has a long history of collecting digitized data. With more and more studies incorporating participants' smartphone sensor and usage data, individual privacy has become a serious concern. Although researchers are trained to exercise confidentiality, sensitive information can be inferred from the smartphone data about the participants and their environment (e.g., families and communities). Without a systematic solution to address privacy concerns, participants may withdraw and request removal of their data from studies.  This project aims to provide privacy protection to study participants during data collection, thus encouraging research participation.  Furthermore, the project demonstrates that meaningful research results can be derived while honoring the participants' privacy preferences.

The project bridges the privacy-enhancing technologies community and social and behavioral research community by focusing on the usefulness and limitations of privacy technologies, collectively. Specifically, the project (1) includes a systematic review of privacy-preserving methods for commonly collected smartphone data types and develops open-source tools compatible with widely adopted research platforms; (2) studies the usefulness of data privacy methods and identifies limitations and open challenges, by incorporating the perspectives of social and behavior researchers; and (3) further studies participant privacy concerns and the utility of privacy-enhanced data through a case study on refugee vocational behavior, which focuses on using survey and mobile behavioral data to predict job-search behaviors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.inst_name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHARLOTTE

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to take an interdisciplinary approach to addressing individual privacy concerns for participating mobile research studies. Overall, the project successfully met the objectives. The key outcomes of this project are summarized in the following.

Understanding individual privacy concerns toward mobile research studies:  This project conducted a large-scale scenario-based survey study to investigate the privacy expectations people have around research data collection practices, with a particular focus on studying differences between immigrants and non-immigrants.

Studying privacy protecting methods for mobile data: This project reviewed and synthesized current privacy methods for mobile data, such as for location data, longitudinal/sensing data, networking data, and visual data.    Furthermore, this project developed novel privacy methods for individual-level data sharing, with a focus on formal privacy models such as differential privacy. 

Supporting research studies and secondary analysis with privacy-enhanced data:  The usefulness of privacy enhanced data has been validated in a range of domains such as geospatial and health studies.  Examples include the study of individual mobility patterns, time-to-event analysis, and anomaly detection.  The project further investigated the effects of privacy methods on deep learning applications as well as the feasibility of deploying state-of-the-art generative models in practical settings for sharing privacy-enhanced data.   

Broader impacts: Beyond the technical goals of the project, contributions were made to 10 invited talks and 8 undergraduate research posters.  The project trained 14 graduate students and 10 undergraduate students at UNC Charlotte and UAlbany for conducting research, coming from academic programs in Biology, Computer Science, Data Science and Business Analytics, Human-Computer Interaction, Mathematics, and Psychology.  Research data and software have been disseminated to the public and for use by other researchers.


Last Modified: 10/17/2023
Modified by: Liyue Fan
